title: Applying Normal Approximation
question_text:
Someone determined that $53\%$ of houses are painted white in a given large town.
Supposing a random sample of $2{,}000\text{ houses}$ were selected, what is the probability that less than half of these houses are painted white?
solution:
Since $2000(0.53)$ and $2000(0.47)$ are each greater than $10$, this binomial distribution is also approximately normal.

$\text{Mean} = nP = 2000\cdot 0.53 = 1060$

$\text{Standard deviation} = \sqrt{(2000\cdot 0.53\cdot 0.47)} = 22.32$

Next, set up the equation: $\dfrac{(1000-1060)}{22.32} = -2.69$

$$P(z > -2.69) = 0.0036$$

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'A'

Sample proportions and the binomial distribution are essentially the same as the binomial distribution. The only difference is that sample proportions involve the proportion of people with white houses, while the binomial distribution involves the number of people with white houses (out of the 2000 surveyed)

Note #2: In this question, and many others, it's essential that one can determine the difference between sample means and sample proportions/binomial. There is an entirely different set of rules for shape, center, and spread for sample means.

Questions involving sample proportions and the binomial distribution have 2 outcomes; yes or no. For example, in the question above, subjects will answer the question, "Is your house painted white" with only a yes or no answer. Sample means, on the other hand, are answered with numbers, An example involving sample means could be: "How much did you have to pay to buy your house?".
